I think that I shall never see
A coed lovely as a tree,
A tree whose limbs are brown and
bare,
And has no dandruff in her hair;
A tree whose head is never pressed
Against someone else's manly breast;
A tree who never wants a meal,
And never tries to make you feel
As if you were a lowly heel.
Coeds are made like fools you see,
But it makes little difference.
—Purdue Exponent.

Students Requested Not
ToSmokeInMemorial Hall
Complaints have come into the
NEWS-LETTER office concerning
smoking in the Gilman Memorial
Room. Officials say that it is undignified to do so, and that it leads to
an ill-kempt appearance of the chamber, since there is no proper receptacle for "butts."
On the bridge between the Library
and the Memorial Room students have
been in the habit of throwing cigarette ends, thus defacing the radiator
casings. Additional information released by the library is that-ash trays
Will be placed on the benches on the
bridge.

From the cotton country comes the
following successful method for getting up in the morning. Two roomsmates in a college dormitory there
put 50 cents on the floor midway between their beds every night. When
the alarm clock rings in the morning, the one getting to the money
first, keeps it.
* * *
A young woman student at the
Cornell University Medical College in
New York took a literacy test in order to vote at the city elections and
just barely passed. One more error
would have classified her as illiterate.

Campus Captains

Dean Berry To Present Paper
On Venezuelan Exploration

This week: BRIAN P. MURPHY.
Murph is among the candidates
for the title of the leading activity
man in the Junior Class. As treasurer of the Y. M. C. A. organization Brian is general chairman of
the Membership Campaign now going on. Last year he was chairman
Of the Sophomore Banquet Committee. In September he was chairman
of the Freshman Camp Committee.
This active Junior is a member of
the Student Council, a vice-president of the Musical Club, and a
Barnstormer, not to forget that
Brian is Junior Manager of football
and secretary 9f the Cotillion Board.
Delta Upsilon finds him a worthy
brother in touch football games. He
conducts a class in Musical Appreciation at Levering Hall. Coming
from a musical family, Murph can
Play the piano, sing, and teach the
subject of music.

Dean Berry will give a paper on
the results of his explorations in
Venezuela during the summer of
1933, at the first meeting of the
National Academy of Sciences, which
will be held at the University of Virginia from November 18th to 20th.

yellow fever will take hold before

INTRA-MURAL
STANDINGS

Badminton League
Under Way Soon

INTERCLASS

W. L. T.

Team
For the second successive year, the
Johns Hopkins University will sponsor the winter play of the Baltimore
Badminton League at the gym.
Play will be held on two nights a
week, and arrangements are being
made for the lining and laying out
of three courts. These courts will be
used by all the member teams of the
league for both practice and tournament play.
In the near future, a tournament
will be held for members of the student body to determine the representative undergraduate team. This
contest is open to all men including
those who were on the team last
year.
The faculty aggregation consists
of Dr. Schaffer, Frank Dotterweich,
Gardner Mallonee, Jimmy Benson,
Dr. Newhall, Dr. Stevens, Dr. Fagin, Dr. Lyons, and Rube Baer.
Last year, both the graduate and
undergraduate teams succeeded in
carrying off honors The graduates
took first place in the city playoffs,
while the undergrads stood high in
their respective division.

I think that I shall never see
A coed lovely as a tree,
A tree whose limbs are brown and
bare,
And has no dandruff in her hair;
A tree whose head is never pressed
Against someone else's manly breast;
A tree who never wants a meal,
And never tries to make you feel
As if you were a lowly heel.
Coeds are made like fools you see,
But it makes little difference.
—Purdue Exponent.

Students Requested Not
ToSmokeInMemorial Hall
Complaints have come into the
NEWS-LETTER office concerning
smoking in the Gilman Memorial
Room. Officials say that it is undignified to do so, and that it leads to
an ill-kempt appearance of the chamber, since there is no proper receptacle for "butts."
On the bridge between the Library
and the Memorial Room students have
been in the habit of throwing cigarette ends, thus defacing the radiator
casings. Additional information released by the library is that-ash trays
Will be placed on the benches on the
bridge.

From the cotton country comes the
following successful method for getting up in the morning. Two roomsmates in a college dormitory there
put 50 cents on the floor midway between their beds every night. When
the alarm clock rings in the morning, the one getting to the money
first, keeps it.
* * *
A young woman student at the
Cornell University Medical College in
New York took a literacy test in order to vote at the city elections and
just barely passed. One more error
would have classified her as illiterate.

Campus Captains

Dean Berry To Present Paper
On Venezuelan Exploration

This week: BRIAN P. MURPHY.
Murph is among the candidates
for the title of the leading activity
man in the Junior Class. As treasurer of the Y. M. C. A. organization Brian is general chairman of
the Membership Campaign now going on. Last year he was chairman
Of the Sophomore Banquet Committee. In September he was chairman
of the Freshman Camp Committee.
This active Junior is a member of
the Student Council, a vice-president of the Musical Club, and a
Barnstormer, not to forget that
Brian is Junior Manager of football
and secretary 9f the Cotillion Board.
Delta Upsilon finds him a worthy
brother in touch football games. He
conducts a class in Musical Appreciation at Levering Hall. Coming
from a musical family, Murph can
Play the piano, sing, and teach the
subject of music.

Dean Berry will give a paper on
the results of his explorations in
Venezuela during the summer of
1933, at the first meeting of the
National Academy of Sciences, which
will be held at the University of Virginia from November 18th to 20th.

INTRA-MURAL
STANDINGS

Badminton League
Under Way Soon

INTERCLASS

W. L. T.

Team
For the second successive year, the
Johns Hopkins University will sponsor the winter play of the Baltimore
Badminton League at the gym.
Play will be held on two nights a
week, and arrangements are being
made for the lining and laying out
of three courts. These courts will be
used by all the member teams of the
league for both practice and tournament play.
In the near future, a tournament
will be held for members of the student body to determine the representative undergraduate team. This
contest is open to all men including
those who were on the team last
year.
The faculty aggregation consists
of Dr. Schaffer, Frank Dotterweich,
Gardner Mallonee, Jimmy Benson,
Dr. Newhall, Dr. Stevens, Dr. Fagin, Dr. Lyons, and Rube Baer.
Last year, both the graduate and
undergraduate teams succeeded in
carrying off honors The graduates
took first place in the city playoffs,
while the undergrads stood high in
their respective division.
